medium: Black crayon and gray wash heightened with white gouache over graphite
creditline: Gift of Frank Jewett Mather Jr.
inscribed:
in graphite, lower center before signature: Design for Lopping, for 'The Farmer's Year'  --
in graphite, throughout: [notations]
signed: Signed, and dated in graphite, lower center: Clare Leighton -- Done 1933-

makers.displaydate: 1898–1989; born London, England; died Woodbury, CT; active Woodbury
makers.displaymaker: Clare Leighton, 1898–1989; born London, England; died Woodbury, CT; active Woodbury

texts.textentryhtml: Of the process of drafting studies for woodblocks, Leighton once asked: “How is it that one is able to carry this initial concept through the hours and weeks of strengthening and simplifying the design, correcting the tone values, and attacking the problem with the critical side of one’s nature, and yet not allow the eventual engraving to show any signs of fatigue? It is the strangest power of alchemy from emotion to fact.” Here, in a sketch for Lopping, the engraving that hangs nearby, you can see how her initial concept—curves so dramatic that she continued their lines outside the frame of the image—developed from simple thumbnails to a full compositional study.
texts.remarks: K2 Corridor: “A Single Drop of Ink for a Mirror”: Nineteenth-Century British Literature and the Visual Arts

bibliography.boilertext: John Wilmerding et al., American Art in the Princeton University Art Museum: volume 1: drawings and watercolors, (Princeton: Princeton University Art Museum; New Haven, CT; London: Yale University Press, 2004)
